title: coronavirus-borders-records-40-cases-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirus in a -hour period, latest figures show.An update was published by the Scottish Government at pm today .And the new data shows that the Borders has now seen , coronavirus cases since the start of the pandemic.There are nine people in hospital in the Borders with recently confirmed cases of COVID-.Scotland has now recorded , cases since March last year.

title: winter-solstice-shortest-day-year-2021
story: As the winter months roll in, the nights are drawing longer and the days shorter - meaning thewinter solstice is just around the corner.The winter solstice marks the shortest day of the year in the UK when we have the fewest hours of daylight.The good newsis that after its over, the days continuously get longer until the summer solstice in June.Heres what you need to know about the shortest day in the UK in ...When is the winter solstice in  The winter solstice will take place on Tuesday December  .On this day, Scotlandwill only see around hours  minutes of daylight.Why does the winter solstice happen The winter solstice occurs in the UK when the north pole reaches its maximum tilt away from the sun.While it only happens once a year in the UK, it happens twice a year across the globe, once in the northern hemisphere and once in the southern hemisphere.The term winter solstice actually refers to the exact moment the earth is tilted furthest away from the sun, however it is also sometimes used to describe the day this occurs.During the winter solstice in the northern hemisphere, the further north you travelthe darker it will be.On December  , the north pole will remain dark for the entire day.From this day onwards, the days will gradually grow longer until the summer solstice six months later, following which the days will again begin to shorten.When is summer solstice The next summer solstice will take place on Tuesday June   in the northern hemisphere, marking the longest day of the year.Summer solstice is when the earth is tilted closest to the sun and is the opposite of the winter solstice.

title: time-nicola-sturgeon-speaking-today-watch-update
story: Nicola Sturgeon will give her weekly Covid announcement to Parliament this afternoon as Scotlandcontinues to record cases of the Omicron iant.The iant, originally identied inSouth Africa, has caused concern around the worldand prompted countries to introduce new measures to try and limit the spread.Scientists are racing to examine the potential impact of the Omicron iant which is feared to be more transmissible than Delta.In line with JCVI advice, the Scottish government confirmed last week it would offer all adults a booster jab to increase protection against the virus.Tighter restrictions on travelhave also been introduced in the UK, with passengers travelling to England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland from abroadrequired to take a pre-departure test from today, regardless of vaccine status.The first ministers statement comes the day after changes were made to the vaccine passport scheme in Scotland, which mean that people can now gain entry to events which require vaccine certication using a negative lateral flow result.As the country continues to grapple with the new Covid iant, heres everything you need to know about Nicola Sturgeons update today...When is Nicola Sturgeon Covid announcement today Nicola Sturgeon will give her update to Parliament on the Covid situation in Scotland around :pm this afternoon.It will depend on the topics before running to schedule, socould be just after :pm.Where can I watch Nicola Sturgeons Covid briefing You can watch the first ministersCovid update via the Scottish governments social media s.It will also be broadcast on BBC Scotland from :pm, and the statement is usually live tweeted from the SNP Twitter handle.What will Nicola Sturgeon say today As always, we will hear an update of the case rates in Scotland, with the figures published daily at pm.The first minister is also likely to give an overview of what the government knows about Omicron and its presence in Scotland..removeIf any further measures are to be introduced to curb the spread of the iant, we are likely to hear about them at the briefing this afternoon.

title: covid-scotland-buy-pcr-test-travel-using-government-list
story: The Covidtravel rules mean that everyone travelling to the UK from overseas must take a private PCR test within -hours of arrival.These tests must be pre-booked and paid for and are not available on the NHS.With lots of options available at ious prices, it can be hard to know where to book your test from.Heres what the government says about booking a PCR test for travel...Are there government approved PCR tests for travel Thegovernmentdoes not endorse, recommend orapproveany privatetestprovider, however you must make sure any test you book is included in the GOV.UK list of providers for the testing service you need.You can find private PCR test providers through either your own research or via theprovider lists on the government websitewhich can be found here.All the providers listed by the governmentmeet the governmentrsquos minimum standards by the United Kingdom Accreditation Service .You can filter the list by location, type of test and testing method.You can choose from swab at home, swab on site, provider supervised at home or provider supervised on site.Some airlines and travel agents also offer discounts on PCR tests, so check with the company you are travelling with to seeyou are eligible.What are the travel rules for the UK The travel rules are the same whether entering Scotland, England, Northern Ireland or Wales due to the four nations approach adopted by the four countries.Everyone, regardless of vaccination status, must now book, pay for andtake a pre-departure test and a post arrival test when travelling to the UK.Fo red listed countries, everyone regardless of vaccination status, must isolate in a quarantine hotel as well as taking day- and day- PCR tests.Meanwhile,you are not fully vaccinated and travelling to the UK from overseas, you must:take a COVID- test ndash to be taken in the days before you travel to England book and pay for day  and day  COVID-PCRtestsndash to be taken after arrival in Englandquarantine at home or in the place you are staying for  full daystake your COVID-PCRtests ndash you mustbook these testsbefore you travel

title: nicola-sturgeon-update-say-today
story: Nicola Sturgeon gave her weekly update to Parliament today amid concerns surrounding the Omicron iant, describing the situation as "another serious moment" of the pandemic.Last week the Scottish government urged people to tighten their compliance with the rules in order to curb the spread of the iant.Scotlandalso introduced travel restrictions in a four nation approach with the other UK countries.Earlier on Tuesday prime minister Boris Johnson said that preliminaryindications suggested the new iant was more transmissible than Delta.This was addressed bythe first minister today who outlinedwhat scientists so far understand about Omicron.As Omicron continues to cause uncertainty in the run-up to Christmas, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today.... Current protections to remain in placeNo changes will be made to the current regulations, however the Scottish government wants the public to tighten compliance with the regulations.The ruleswill be monitored daily due to the new iant, with the government able to bring in further measuresrequired.The first minister said the Scottish government will seek to do what is necessary to prevent the problem, and will therefore "strive" to act both proportionately andpreventatively evenat the cost of popularity."For the Scottish Government, our first principle will be to seek to do what is necessary to keep the country as safe as possible, eventhat is sometimes at the expense of being popular."And second, we will strive to get the right balance between acting proportionately and acting preventatively.". Rise in overall number of casesCases have risen over the past -daysin all age cohorts under .The first minister said: "In total, cases amongst under s increased by % in the past week - and since people under  currently account for more than % of cases overall, that has inevitably driven an increase in the total number of cases recorded.".remove. More details on confirmed Omicron cases in Scotland coming tomorrowMore detailed information onthe number of Omicron cases in Scotland is due tomorrow.In the coming weeks, more data will become available on the hospitalisations and deaths linked to the Omicron iant, with the first minister saying: "In weeks to come - and as the quality of data allows - these reports will also provide details on the vaccination status of, and hospital admissions and deaths associated with, Omicron cases.". Ten fold increase in Omicron in a single weekOmicron cases in Scotland have increased from  to  cases in the space of a week.Like Boris Johnson this morning, Nicola Sturgeon also said that early evidence suggests that the Omicron iant is more transmissible than Delta.She warned to expect a rapid rise of cases in the coming days.. People asked to work from homeThe first minister urged employers whose employees were working from home earlier in the pandemic to allow them to do so again.This working from home advice will remain in place until the middle of January when it will be reviewed.. , new Covid casesOver , Covid cases were recorded over the past -hours, however this higher number of cases was due to a backlog of results which Public HealthScotland expects to clear today.people were in hospital yesterday with recently confirmed COVID-, while were in intensive care.

title: covid-scotland-work-home
story: Nicola Sturgeon is urgingthe Scottish workforce to workfrom home in the run-up to Christmas as the Omicron iant of Covid becomes more prevalent.In a statement on Tuesday afternoon, the First Minister asked employers to allow their staff to work from home where possible in order to help "stem transmission and avoid the need for even more onerous measures."She said: "We already advise people to work from home where practical. Today, I am asking employers to ensure this is happening."To be blunt,you had staff working from home at this start of the pandemic, please now enable them to do so again."We are asking you to do this from now until the middle of January when we will review this advice again."But who exactly was working from home at the start of the pandemic Heres what we know...Who is the Scottish Government asking to work from home The Scottish Government is asking anyone who worked from home at the start of the pandemic to do so once again until mid-January.At the beginningof the pandemic in March , Nicola Sturgeon said that it was up to employers to decideworking from home was feasible.Now, almost two years later, she is once again calling on employers to make the call.At the start of the pandemic, it was largely only key workerswho could go into work, while everyone  was told to work from home.Key workers were ided into three categories:Category Health and care workers directly supporting Covid response, and associated staffHealth and care workers supporting le-threatening emergency work, as well as critical primary and community care provisionEnergy suppliers and staff providing childcare learning for other Category  staff.Category All other healthand care workers, and wider public sector workers providing emergency critical welfare services ,Those supporting our critical national infrastructure, without whom serious damage to the welfare of the people of Scotlandcould be caused..removeCategory All workerswithout whom there could be a signicant impact on Scotland Of course, at the start of the pandemic, non-essential businesses that could not operate from home were told to shut and their employees were put on furlough.This time mass closures have not been introduced meaning people working from home will largely be those who are office-based.How long is the work from home advice in place The work from home advice is in place until the middle of January according to the First Minister.In January, it will be reviewed again.Why hashome working been so strongly advised According to the First Minister, home working could play a key role in curbing the spread of Omicron.After asking people who worked at home at the beginning of the pandemic to do so again, she concluded: "Please - and I really hope this will be for one last time in this pandemic - letrsquos all pull together, do what is necessary, and get each other and the country through this winter and into what we all hope will be a better and brighter spring."

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: winter-wonderland-coming-gosford-house-december
story: Gosford House, near Longniddry, will play host to Scotlandrsquos newest Winter Wonderland between December  and .Event designers Rogue Village and Rogue City will create a vintage-inspired Christmas experience befitting of its historic backdrop featuring a Victorian carousel and chair swings, Christmas land train trips around the grounds, carnival stalls, marketplace, donkeys and a Christmas tree post-box maze.Jenner Maniam, Rogue Village co-director, said: ldquoWersquore creating something that captures the magic of Christmas ndash something that makes everyone feel like a six-year-old on Christmas Eve.ldquoThis year more than most we want people to be able to be socialise with loved ones in a safe environment.Those wishing to explore inside the incredible Gosford House can book a house tour or take part in workshops and festive activities.These include Christmas table styling by Style Your Spaces, whisky tasting from Glenkinchie, wreath making from Feathergrass Florals and ballet classes from Art East, former Royal Ballet principal dancers.Alison Bombail, Gosford venue manager, added: ldquoWe want to bring an authentic Christmas experience to our locality, while celebrating the local talent we are so lucky to be surrounded with.ldquoWe also hope to see lots of families joining in the festive cheer.Some of Scotlands leading independent food and drink producers, artists and designers will be available at the market stalls.Traders will include Bon Tot, The Portobello Bookshop and Dook.Peter Maniam, co-director, said: "Wersquore steering away from the strangely traditional German market and creating a marketplace that is representative of the incredible independent brands here in Scotland."We want to encourage spending and supporting local."The food and drink area sponsored by Wemyss Malts will include cosy tipi tents complete with open fire.Food and drink will be provided by Steampunk Coffee, Herringbone, Fox Hat, Wild at Heart and The Wee Green Van.To book tickets or for more information visit www.roguevillage gosford-house-winterwonderland

title: musselburgh-choir-touring-county-weekend
story: The Clark Community Choir is back in action after the easing of Covid- restrictions and, after performing at Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, Santarsquos Grotto at the Ship Inn in Musselburgh, and the Christmas lights switch-on in Tranent last weekend, the group is set to tour the county this Saturday.The singers will be on Musselburgh High Street, beside BM, -.am outside the Scottish Seabird Centre in North Berwick, .am-.pm at The Mart, East Linton, .-.pm outside Haddington Corn Exchange, .-pm and at the Ship Inn, Musselburgh, -.pm.Suzanne Walker, a committee member, said: ldquoWe are really excited to be out performing for this year, as we havenrsquot been out since March .During the Covid- lockdown, the choir, led by choir leader Kirsty Robertson, kept up regular practice sessions via Zoom, enjoyed online quiz nights, musical evenings and even a Christmas party.ldquoWe were delighted to have our first in-person practice in June this year, said Suzanne.ldquoNewhailes House was kind enough to let us practise on their front lawn on a Sunday evening so we could socially distance but sing together.ldquoI think we even entertained some of the evening walkers.She added: ldquoWe would love to help make this Christmas extra special for everyone.Performances will continue at the following venues: Ship Inn, Musselburgh, Sunday, December , .-pm Ship Inn, Sunday, December , .-pm Haddington Farmersrsquo Market, Saturday, December , -.am Ship Inn, Sunday, December , .-pm.The choir, whose motto is lsquogenerations singing togetherrsquo, was formed in , following the death of Robert Clark, founder of Musselburghrsquos St Ninianrsquos Junior Concert Party in .Mr Clark, a chemistry teacher at both Musselburgh Grammar and Newbattle High Schools, also took children all over Britain and Europe on holidays.He retired at the age of  and, six months after being named Musselburghrsquos Citizen of the Year in , he passed away suddenly and unexpectedly at the age of  ndash just two weeks before a grand reunion was to be held for the concert partyrsquos th birthday.Following the reunion, a choir was formed by former and current concert party members.An invitation was thrown open to the community to join and the group was named the Clark Community Choir in tribute to Mr Clark.The choir exists for anyone of any age, background or ability who enjoys singing, whether they consider themselves a lsquosingaphobicrsquo, an expert or somewhere in between.It seeks to unite generations in a common purpose: singing popular music for pleasure.

title: musselburgh-duos-gardening-exploits-see-become-internet-stars
story: Eli Appleby-Donald, , and we KathrynAppleby-Donald, , have created a YouTube channel and website ndash The Kitchen Garden with Eli and Kate ndash aimed at making gardening ldquosimple, easy and fun for everyone.From the garden in the Honest Toun, Eli, a digital teaching specialist at the University of Edinburgh, and Kate, head of collections at the Scottish Parliament, have produced more than  videos which focus on gardening, growing food and flowers.Their YouTube channel now has , subscribers, attracting about , views from  countries.Eli said: ldquoWe had a website and blog that we started back in  when we moved into this house.ldquoAlthough, to be honest, we did it for family to keep them updated and never expected anyone other than our family to read it.ldquoKatersquos mum had been diagnosed with Alzheimerrsquos, so the blog was meant as a way for her to see what we were doing.ldquoWe were really surprised when we started getting messages from folk who had found it and enjoyed it.She said: ldquoWe started making videos to share on the blog, again thinking only a few folk who read the blog would watch them.ldquoBut towards the end of , we started to get a lot more people watching the videos than reading the blog, so I tried to learn a bit more about making videos to make them better.ldquoWhen Covid hit and we all went into lockdown, I really missed being in the classroom but I had been working with students who donrsquot normally delve into the digital world and Irsquod been teaching them to make videos and blog.ldquoI was hearing from them about how much that meant to them to have this outlet while they were locked down and I realised that I was getting something similar from YouTube.Eli said they had done a lot on greenhouse growing because, when they started, they were growing tomatoes and peppers.She added: ldquoI also talk about how to grow from seed to save money because itrsquos a lot cheaper than buying plants.ldquoWersquove done some cooking videos, too ndash things like making passata with the tomatoes yoursquove grown or we did easy sourdough during lockdown.She added: ldquoThe videos are meant as a lsquofriend in the garden with yoursquo idea.ldquoWe only make videos about what we are doing in the garden and specically for growing in Scotland.The couple, who got married in their garden, have covered topics such as mulch, how to sharpen your garden tools, how to get your tomatoes to ripen, how to monitor greenhouse temperatures and composting.Eli said: ldquoIt wasnrsquot until we moved to Musselburgh that I fell in love with gardening.ldquoWhen we bought the house, there werenrsquot really any gardens. The front had been paved over and the back was just a lawn. So, I think we were maybe lucky that we got to design our garden to suit us and start from scratch. It helped fire the passion for gardening, I think.ldquoIrsquove been absolutely astounded at how many amazing folk watch our videos every week. We have had loads of lovely messages from folk saying how much theyrsquove enjoyed learning to garden with us over lockdown and beyond, and how wersquove taken the fear out of it.ldquoThere were even a few messages that made me cry where people have talked about their personal situations and what joy they get from our videos, and how they have made me a part of their weekly ritual.ldquoFolk from all over the world seem to really connect with what we are doing and how we are teaching in our videos, so itrsquos lovely when we get messages telling us what itrsquos been like in their towns and countries, and wersquove made some lovely friends from the US and Canada to Australia, India and even Thailand.ldquoIrsquom so, so glad that folk have found happiness and comfort in our daftness.Catch up with Eli and Kate at youtube c TheKitchenGardenwithEliandKate or thekitchengardenwitheliandkate

title: msp-hears-opportunities-blindwells-visit
story: Martin Whitfield, a South Scotland MSP, visited the new town of Blindwells on November .More than , homes are being built on the site, between Tranent, Prestonpans and Longniddry, alongside plans for education and healthcare services, retail and leisure facilities.Mr Whitfield, Labourrsquos Shadow Minister for Children and Young People, Lelong Learning and Youth Employment, saw first-hand the opportunities available in construction, as well as the skills needed to help the industryrsquos growth.The former primary school teacher said: ldquoIrsquom pleased to see that Blindwells is now making real progress and helping to create new job and apprenticeship opportunities for young people.ldquoWith hundreds of houses and new public infrastructure being built at the development over the coming years, the site will offer a wide range of ways to build a career in construction.ldquoI welcome these new skilled jobs and look forward to seeing many more local young people forging a career in the industry.More than  new homes are currently being built at Blindwells, which will feature a new school among its amenities, and work is due to start early next year by Persimmon on another  residential properties.In recent weeks, five acres of land have also been launched for exclusive use by businesses seeking new commercial property opportunities in the county.Once complete, the development could see up to , new homes.Iain Slater, development and estates director at Hargreaves Land, the development company behind the Blindwells scheme, said: ldquoAhead of the first residents moving into Blindwells in the weeks ahead, our team has been hard at work applying impeccable standards in building a town that will be a relaxing yet vibrant part of the East Lothian landscape.ldquoIt was an honour for myself and development director Bruce Lindsay to show Mr Whitfield our progress in making a modern and sustainable urban environment in which families and businesses can thrive.

title: man-ordered-good-behaviour-pushing-partner
story: David Morley acted in an aggressive manner and pushed the woman on the body at their home at Lydgait in Haddington.Edinburgh Sherf Court was told that Morley, , and the woman both worked for the same bank and their relationship was to continue.Sherf Matthew Auchincloss heard that Morley had been attending counselling and ordered the first offender to stay out of trouble until he appeared back at court next May. Sentence was deferred for good behaviour.Morley admitted an amended charge of behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by acting in an aggressive manner and pushing a woman on the body on July .

title: charity-pupils-bring-joy-cards
story: Our Community Kitchenhas launched Our Kindness Cards, with hundreds of small cards set to be delivered to care home residents, day centres and more.The charity was set up to reduce social isolation by bringing people together to share fresh, home-cooked food and allowing friendships to form in a kind and caring environment.The themed cards will be delivered during the festive period, with a view to revamping them for other occasions.Elaine Gale, from OCK, which is based in Haddington Bowling Club, was thrilled with the initiative.She said: ldquoThe idea is to spread some joy by working with our local schools in the Haddington and Lammermuir area to produce Our Kindness Cards, which are small, themed postcard-size cards.ldquoThe cards will be handed into schools for pupils to draw or write something positive and these will be distributed to people in care homes, our local hospital, assisted living complexes, to participants of OCK and day centres.ldquoDuring the first Covid- lockdown, some wonderful pupils at Knox Academy decided to write positive notes that were attached to our meal bags and delivered out across the community.ldquoThe feedback was fantastic, with many people saying how much of a dference it made to them during such a dreadful time.ldquoOur volunteer Stuart Pe-Win came up with the idea of a card and we decided to name them Our Kindness Cards.ldquoOur volunteer Carol Lumsden designed the cards and we will be collecting  this week that will be distributed out to our schools and then collected by our volunteers to then distribute out across our community.ldquoWe have had a very positive response from our schools, who are delighted to be involved.The charity played a key role in Haddingtonrsquos resilience efforts at the height of the coronavirus pandemic. Instead of welcoming people through the doors of the bowling club, it delivered hot meals to people in the community.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for health and social care, welcomed the new project.The Haddington and Lammermuir ward member said: ldquoThis is a lovely project which promotes kindness and connection between generations. Itrsquos such a simple idea but will have a great impact and I commend Our Community Kitchen for the initiative, and schools for becoming involved so readily.ldquoI hope the children get as much pleasure from writing their messages as Irsquom sure the recipients will get from reading them.

title: bid-renew-planning-permission-substation-former-cockenzie-power-station-site-covid-delays
story: Operator Inch Cape Offshore Limitedhas lodged a fresh planning applicationfor the building after it said it would not be able to meet the current deadline of February.It is seeking new planning permission in principle for the substation, which will bring in power from its planned offshore windfarm off the Angus coast, with a new deadline to be set after September .The substation, which has been dubbed a ldquogiant shed by local community councillors, is one of only two projects to be given the go-ahead on the -hectare site, which was bought by East Lothian Council in .The local authority took ownership of thesite and surrounding land from ScottishPower after producing its Cockenzie masterplan ndash a visionary document outlining community hopes and economic opportunities for it.However, to date only ICOL and Seagreen ndash which also plans to build a substation to bring energy from an offshore windfarm onto land ndash have gained planning approval for a project on the site.ICOLrsquos planning permission was controversially granted by Scottish Ministers after they called in the application, taking the decision out of East Lothian Councilrsquos hands, in .East Lothian Council approved Seagreenrsquos proposals in August this year, citing the fact that ICOL already had the go-ahead for a similar project.However, ICOLrsquos permission runs out in a few months and it said that, due to the Covid- pandemic, it had been unable to produce the detailed designs needed to take the project forward.In its new application, it says that the offshore wind farm, which will have  turbines, will be operational in the next five years, with a - target date.And it points out that the new application is the same as the one, which was approved by Scottish Ministers, so should be given the go-ahead, as well as citing Seagreenrsquos planning permission as a reason to grant its new request.The application is currently under consideration and can be viewed on the councilrsquos planning portal.

title: early-return-pre-pandemic-opening-hours-paying-off-east-lothians-sports-centre
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos arms- leisure company enjoyleisure said that nearly  per cent of its members had ed, compared to as low as  per cent in some local authority areas.Chief executive Bill Axon said that the ldquorisky decision to reopen the centres in the county at normal times had been a success.Presenting the firmrsquos annual report to the councilrsquos audit and governance committee last week, Mr Axon said: ldquoWe are in the top quartile,not the top of the Premier League, in terms of the number of customers who ed to use our facilities, which is touching  per cent, while the average in the rest of the country is  per cent.The committee heard that enjoyleisure had seen an  per cent fall in customers using its sports centres between April  and March , when they remained closed for a large part of the time.However, visitors to its golf courses rose by nearly  per cent, with an additional , golfers using them.The operational loss for the company was pound,, nearly half of what had been predicted at the start of the pandemic.Mr Axon said that the decision to reopen centres at pre-pandemic hours following lockdown had seen a huge rise in people ing to them.He said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with the council on what was a groundbreaking approach because in general, most other organisations similar to enjoy and other local authorities did not open up all of their facilities from the outset and, indeed, provided a reduced service deliveryto its communities.ldquoThat did not happen in East Lothian and our approach was quite clear. We wanted to reopen and give confidence back to our communities that their facilities were opening in a safe environment that they could come and visit.ldquoSo whilst there was a risk attached to the decision, it was great that we could work together to ensure we were ahead of the game in terms of customersrsquo s.Despite the strong , Mr Axon told the committee that enjoyleisure did not expect toto pre-Covid membership or income for another two years.But he said that things were looking up, with the predicted income from September this year, the first month after all restrictions had been lted in the centres, expected to be double the amount taken in August.He told the committee that  members of staff were furloughed during lockdown, equating to  per cent of the workforce.And he praised his employees for all their hard work bringing the sport centres and facilities back into use.He said: ldquoI want to put on record our appreciation of all our staff who have gone above and beyond their duties.

title: fashion-shop-welcomes-dogs-bid-tempt-owners-back-high-street
story: The clothing retailer will welcome all customers canine companions, not just assistance animals, in shops across the country.Shoppers can now enter stores in Haddington and Musselburgh with their four-legged friend in tow.MCo said: "We are paw-leased to announce you can now bring your four-legged friends into the store with you."No dog need be fur-gotten outside, we canrsquot wait to meet them."

title: brave-teenager-leukaemia-returns-school-first-time
story: Aidan Hogg, , of Arrow Crescent, Musselburgh, has been mainly bed-bound at Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Children and Young Peoplesince he was diagnosed with acute myeloid leukaemia in March.Aidan is now making weekly visits to his family home as he continues to receive intense physiotherapy in hospital.His mum, Emma Davidson, said the Preston Lodge High School pupil was delighted toto his high school for the first time in eight months for a short visit.The teenager dropped by for  minutes to visit staff members, who his mum said ldquohe was desperate to see and thank for all their support.Staff and students at the high school recently banded together to raise funds for Aidanrsquos Magical Gts ndash a project set up by the youngster to provide Christmas gts for over  children at RHCYP.Following a dress down day at the school in October, a representative was proud to announce that pound had been raised for the cause, with a generous donation of pound from a friend of the school bringing the total amount to pound,.Julia Robertson, deputy headteacher, said: ldquoWith those funds we are buying an advent door from the Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charity, who organise fun things for children and young people in hospital, and  Amazon gt cards for the gt bags.ldquoWersquore looking forward to welcoming Aidan back into school soon too!Recently, Aidan underwent an important milestone in his recovery when he had his port removed.Installed  weeks ago, the port administered chemotherapy, fluids, antibiotics, and food when the teenager was too unwell to eat.Emma added: ldquoSo many times we have seen him hooked up to dferent things through that port.ldquoI know itrsquos been amazing for the staff to get the things he needs into his body the fastest way but I canrsquot say I will be sad to see it go.ldquoI was so nervous for the surgery but also happy for him and for us all.

title: fate-rail-underpass-depends-new-housing-scheme-decision-dunbar
story: Hundreds of new homes have been built at Hallhill, south of the railway line, in Dunbar in recent years.However, pedestrian links between the new homes and the older section of Dunbar are limited.East Lothian Council is keen to see a new pedestrian underpass to improve connections, which could be financed in part through another housing development in the area.It is expected that the cost of the underpass would be more than pound million, with part of the cost being covered by the Hallhill North development, which would consist of  houses and  flats.A decision is set to be made on the plans, which come from Taylor Wimpey East Scotland and Hallhill Developments Limited, at a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee on Tuesday.Councillor Norman Hampshire, who chairs the local authorityrsquos planning committee and represents Dunbar on East Lothian Council, noted that currently the only pedestrian access in the area was under the railway line beside Hallhill Sports Centre.He said: ldquoAs part of the application, the developer will be making a contribution to a new underpass at the railway.ldquoThere will not be enough funding coming from the developer to completely do this underpass.ldquoThat has to be done through grant funding from other agencies and the council themselves.ldquoAt the moment, all the houses from the Hallhill area to get to both the lower primary school and secondary school have to come underneath the tunnel, and children going to the Lochend Campus have to come back through that one.ldquoIt is really congested and we definitely need another way through there.An underpass was previously in place under the railway line but it was blocked up a number of years ago.Network Rail was approached about seeing it reopened but was not keen on the idea and East Lothian Council would have been liable for the structure.Mr Hampshire said: ldquoWe have to go with a completely new cut-through for pedestrians and cyclists, which will come through into Ash Grove swing park area but will be a safe route to get to the secondary school.Drawings and documents for the planning application were first submitted to East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department at the beginning of February last year.The scheme, to the west of the primary schoolrsquos Lochend Campus, originally featured  houses and  apartments.

title: musselburgh-grammar-school-host-first-outdoor-christmas-market
story: The event, from am to pm, has been organised by S pupils studying National  retailing.The initiative also involves S digital enterprise and S business pupils, as well as other groups within the school. The music department will present Christmas carols. Tea, coffee and Christmas treats will also be served.Entry is free to the market at the school but, due to Covid- regulations, tickets must be allocated prior to the event. Donations for Pupil Equity Funds will be welcome on entry.Email mgschristmasmarket@edubuzz.org for more information and, to register, go to Eventbrite via bit.ly riOAvC

title: rising-star-joins-east-festival-2022-line-up
story: He will join headliners The Kooks and Ministry of Sound Classical, plus Shed Seven, Circa Waves, Sister Sledge and The Futureheads.The two-day, family-friendly festival will feature a erse blend of live music, street food, art, culture and wellbeing events on August  and  next year.Callum played a special set ahead of Scotlandrsquos first Autumn Nations Series rugby match against Tonga at Murrayfield in October has had a sold-out Scottish tour and will be supporting fellow Scottish musician Amy Macdonald on her UK tour, including a show at the OVO Hydro in Glasgow this month.Callumrsquos debut album, People Like Us, reached No.  in The Official Scottish Album Chart and No.  in The Official UK Album Sales Charts last year.Shane Grieve, Out East Festival director, said: ldquoWersquore back, bigger and better for . The summer will be all about celebrating the good things in le and wersquore delighted that Out East will be at the centre of that.Stephen Begg, operations manager at Dalkeith Country Park, added: ldquoWe are ecstatic to be hosting Out East Festival  at Dalkeith Country Park. We canrsquot wait. The parkrsquos expanse of beautul greenery is the perfect backdrop for this vibrant music, art and culture-focussed, family-friendly event.In addition to the musical line-up, Out East will offer a well-being area, lsquoThe Breakoutrsquo, nestled amongst the trees with wildle.At lsquoThe Outpostrsquo, an open-air cabaret stage, an eclectic mix of art and culture, including comedy and dance theatre, will take place. Everything from storytelling, science and circus activities is available at lsquoSchoolrsquos Outrsquo, while lsquoThe Pig Outrsquo will be curated by Canteen, offering ious culinary delights. A fairground can also be enjoyed at lsquoFar Outrsquo.For more information, go to outeastfest

title: improvement-plans-revealed-1m-restoration-project
story: More than pound million was set aside earlier this year for the late medieval towerhouse in Prestonpans.Originally constructed in the th century, it was then repaired and extended upwards in the th century.The two-phase project will include improved access and encouraging more people to visit the site.The plans, which are now with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department, show a new path and an interpretation  to explain about the building and its surroundings.The funding for the scheme was secured through the Scottish Governmentrsquos Town Centre Fund and Place Based Investment Programme.

title: daffodils-bring-colour-path-next-spring
story: The Narcissus Jetfire bulbs are being planted at the lsquopugrsquo path as part of a joint initiative by Wallyford Community Council, Musselburgh Area Partnership and East Lothian Council.A total of , bulbs will bring colour to the area ndash where a replica of the pug, or short steam engine, which used to transport coal and bricks to the main East Coast rail line, is situated.Alister Hadden, community council chairman, said: ldquoThis display of Narcissus Jetfire bulbs stretching along the Wallyford lsquopugrsquo path will show families and youngsters going to school, along with everyone who passes along Salters Road, that spring has retuned, bringing new le and colour to another area of our village and giving us a sign that summer is on its way.The pug was used to carry coal and bricks in wagons at a time when the coal mines and brickworks were in operation in the s and early s. A stone buffer for the pug, known locally as lsquothe pound of cheesersquo due to its shape, still sits in the public park.The Old Musselburgh Club also organised the planting of  daffodil bulbs at the memorial stone at Wallyford, which marks the Battle of Pinkie Cleugh.

title: energy-trial-adds-7m-local-economy
story: SP Energy Networks and partners began an active network managementtrial in the town in .The four-year scheme explored how innovative technology could be used where the energy network was constrained.ANM is a way of managing connections into the electricity network, which is responsible for connecting generation, such as renewables, into the grid.As Scotland works towards its goal of net zero by , more and more renewables are needed to reach this target.The trial enabled four new projects, totalling MW of generation, to connect to an export-constrained network.The projects were: Viridor, Dunbar Hoprigshiels Wind Farm, near Oldhamstocks and Cockburnspath Kinegar Wind Farm, near Cockburnspath and Ferneylea Wind Farm, near Oldhamstocks.The trial also benefited the existing MW Aikengall Wind Farm to upgrade from its previous constrained connection to an ANM flexible connection.In addition, through the increase in generation in the local area, the trial reduced carbon emissions, helped with the creation of  full-time equivalent jobs, provided pound, of community benefit for the letime of the connected projects and added poundm to the Scottish economy, of which more than poundm was in the local area.Scott Mathieson, network planning and regulation director at SP Energy Networks, said: ldquoOur electricity networks are at the heart of this climate ambition they support the growth of renewables as well as the increase of electric heating and transport.ldquoItrsquos our job to ensure that we are constantly innovating and investing in our network to make sure it stands ready to support the energy transition.

title: section-road-closed-resurfacing-works
story: Repairs will be carried out at Langriggs in Haddington.David Barrett, a community council member, highlighted the state of the surface.He added: ldquoThey are also going to put yellow lines there to restrict people parking because some people could not get out of their garage.

title: nicola-sturgeon-covid-update-today-watch-live
story: The iant, originally identied inSouth Africa, has caused concern around the world and prompted countries to introduce new measures to try and limit the spread.Scientists are racing to examine the potential impact of the Omicron iant which is feared to be more transmissible than Delta.In line with JCVI advice, the Scottish government confirmed last week it would offer all adults a booster jab to increase protection against the virus.Tighter restrictions on travel have also been introduced in the UK, with passengers travelling to England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland from abroadrequired to take a pre-departure test from today, regardless of vaccine status.The first ministers statement comes the day after changes were made to the vaccine passport scheme in Scotland, which mean that people can now gain entry to events which require vaccine certication using a negative lateral flow result.As the country continues to grapple with the new Covid iant, heres everything you need to know about Nicola Sturgeons update today...Nicola Sturgeon will give her update to Parliament on the Covid situation in Scotland around :pm this afternoon.It will depend on the topics before running to schedule, socould be just after :pm.You can watch the first ministersCovid update via the Scottish governments social media s.It will also be broadcast on BBC Scotland from :pm, and the statement is usually live tweeted from the SNP Twitter handle.As always, we will hear an update of the case rates in Scotland, with the figures published daily at pm.The first minister is also likely to give an overview of what the government knows about Omicron and its presence in Scotland.If any further measures are to be introduced to curb the spread of the iant, we are likely to hear about them at the briefing this afternoon.

title: covid-scotland-buy-pcr-test-travel-using-government-list
story: These tests must be pre-booked and paid for and are not available on the NHS.With lots of options available at ious prices, it can be hard to know where to book your test from.Heres what the government says about booking a PCR test for travel...Thegovernmentdoes not endorse, recommend orapproveany privatetestprovider, however you must make sure any test you book is included in the GOV.UK list of providers for the testing service you need.You can find private PCR test providers through either your own research or via theprovider lists on the government websitewhich can be found here.All the providers listed by the governmentmeet the governmentrsquos minimum standards by the United Kingdom Accreditation Service .You can filter the list by location, type of test and testing method.You can choose from swab at home, swab on site, provider supervised at home or provider supervised on site.Some airlines and travel agents also offer discounts on PCR tests, so check with the company you are travelling with to seeyou are eligible.The travel rules are the same whether entering Scotland, England, Northern Ireland or Wales due to the four nations approach adopted by the four countries.Everyone, regardless of vaccination status, must now book, pay for andtake a pre-departure test and a post arrival test when travelling to the UK.Fo red listed countries, everyone regardless of vaccination status, must isolate in a quarantine hotel as well as taking day- and day- PCR tests.Meanwhile,you are not fully vaccinated and travelling to the UK from overseas, you must:

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-update-say-today
story: Last week the Scottish government urged people to tighten their compliance with the rules in order to curb the spread of the iant.Scotland also introduced travel restrictions in a four nation approach with the other UK countries.Earlier on Tuesday prime minister Boris Johnson said that preliminaryindications suggested the new iant was more transmissible than Delta.This was addressed bythe first minister today who outlinedwhat scientists so far understand about Omicron.As Omicron continues to cause uncertainty in the run-up to Christmas, heres what we learned from Nicola Sturgeons Covid update today...No changes will be made to the current regulations, however the Scottish government wants the public to tighten compliance with the regulations.The ruleswill be monitored daily due to the new iant, with the government able to bring in further measuresrequired.The first minister said the Scottish government will seek to do what is necessary to prevent the problem, and will therefore "strive" to act both proportionately andpreventatively evenat the cost of popularity."For the Scottish Government, our first principle will be to seek to do what is necessary to keep the country as safe as possible, eventhat is sometimes at the expense of being popular."And second, we will strive to get the right balance between acting proportionately and acting preventatively."Cases have risen over the past -days, in all age cohorts under .The first minister said: "In total, cases amongst under s increased by % in the past week - and since people under  currently account for more than % of cases overall, that has inevitably driven an increase in the total number of cases recorded."More detailed information onthe number of Omicron cases in Scotland is due tomorrow.In the coming weeks, more data will become available on the hospitalisations and deaths linked to the Omicron iant, with the first minister saying: "In weeks to come - and as the quality of data allows - these reports will also provide details on the vaccination status of, and hospital admissions and deaths associated with, Omicron cases.". Ten fold increase in Omicron in a single weekOmicron cases in Scotland have increased from  to  cases in the space of a week.Like Boris Johnson this morning, Nicola Sturgeon also said that early evidence suggests that the Omicron iant is more transmissible than Delta.She warned to expect a rapid rise of cases in the coming days.The first minister urged employers whose employees were working from home earlier in the pandemic to allow them to do so again.This working from home advice will remain in place until the middle of January when it will be reviewed.Over , Covid cases were recorded over the past -hours, however this higher number of cases was due to a backlog of results which Public Health Scotland expects to clear today.people were in hospital yesterday with recently confirmed COVID-, while were in intensive care.

title: covid-scotland-work-home
story: In a statement on Tuesday afternoon, the First Minister asked employers to allow their staff to work from home where possible in order to help "stem transmission and avoid the need for even more onerous measures."She said: "We already advise people to work from home where practical. Today, I am asking employers to ensure this is happening."To be blunt,you had staff working from home at this start of the pandemic, please now enable them to do so again."We are asking you to do this from now until the middle of January when we will review this advice again."But who exactly was working from home at the start of the pandemic Heres what we know...The Scottish Government is asking anyone who worked from home at the start of the pandemic to do so once again until mid-January.At the beginningof the pandemic in March , Nicola Sturgeon said that it was up to employers to decideworking from home was feasible.Now, almost two years later, she is once again calling on employers to make the call.At the start of the pandemic, it was largely only key workerswho could go into work, while everyone  was told to work from home.Key workers were ided into three categories:Category Category Category Of course, at the start of the pandemic, non-essential businesses that could not operate from home were told to shut and their employees were put on furlough.This time mass closures have not been introduced meaning people working from home will largely be those who are office-based.The work from home advice is in place until the middle of January according to the First Minister.In January, it will be reviewed again.According to the First Minister, home working could play a key role in curbing the spread of Omicron.After asking people who worked at home at the beginning of the pandemic to do so again, she concluded: "Please - and I really hope this will be for one last time in this pandemic - letrsquos all pull together, do what is necessary, and get each other and the country through this winter and into what we all hope will be a better and brighter spring."

title: new-smart-wind-turbine-set-trialled-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: A scaled-down prototype of the new windsurf turbine would be placed at the former Cockenzie Power Station site as part of an -month trial, under new plans submitted to East Lothian Council.The innovative design of the turbine has been described by Edinburgh-based producers Swt TG Energy Ltd as a "game-changer".Designer Sam Dickinson said that the company had worked for years to come up with a design which would be more productive, generate less noise and reduce risk to wildle.He said: ldquoThis is a very early prototype we are testing, it is a new form of aerodynamics.ldquoIt will have less of an environmental impact on birdle and noise. If it works, it will be a game-changer.The firm has applied for planning permission to place a miniature version of the new windsurf turbine on the power station site for  months to monitor its effectiveness.Mr Dickinson said that theof time would give the company a full yearrsquos access to trialling the turbine in all seasons on the exposed coastal site.The turbine itself, which he describes as looking like an upside-down egg whisk, features five blades which are electronically operated and computer controlled.The smart technology allows the computer to move the blades with the wind to gain maximum energy from it, as well as monitoring for any kind of impact.Mr Dickinson compared it to having Olympic sailor Ben Ainslie at the helm of five sails, controlling them in the wind during a race to get the best performance.And he said: ldquoThe technology involved means thatthere was an impact from a bird, it would instantly shut down and we would know it had happened. The sameit was struck by a JCB.ldquoThis dfers from the rotaryturbines, which continue to rotate.It is understood that the company has agreed with East Lothian Council ahead of any planning consent that, should an incident occur onsite involving the death of a bird or breach of noise levels, the trial will shut down.The company has worked with RSPB experts in designing the turbine, which Mr Dickinson said had been years in the making.He said: ldquoThis is the first time we are putting our heads over the parapet, as such, with this prototype and publicly revealing our work.The application is for the siting of the lsquonovelrsquo wind turbine on the site for  months only to trial it. A mobile office and chemical toilet would also be onsite for that duration.It would require a -square-metre area in the north of the former power station site to be fenced off for the duration.Plans are with East Lothian Council and can be viewed on the planing portal.

title: snack-van-shore-road-car-park-john-muir-way-dunbar-approved
story: The plans for the van at the Shore Road car park, on the John Muir Way at Belhaven, drew  protests and were described by one elected councillor as ldquosacrilege.Local residents pleaded with East Lothian Councilrsquos planning committee to refuse planning permission, arguing it went against everything naturalist John Muir, who was born in Dunbar, stood for and strived to achieve.Other residents pointed to road safety concerns on the streets surrounding the car park, which at one point last year saw , vehicles a day visiting it.Local residents said that their streets were already jammed by the overspill of the car park, which sits near a popular surf school which operates from the bay, adding that the snack van would only attract more visitors.One man said thathe left his home to go grocery shopping at the weekend, he wouldto find he could not park within half a mile of his home, adding: ldquoIf that is not impacting on my amenity, I donrsquot know what is.However, Councillor Norman Hampshire, local ward councillor, council leader and planning convenor, insisted that the snack van ndash which will be powered by batteries rather than a generator and use compostable cutlery ndash would be a welcome addition for people who visited the beach and walked the John Muir Way.He told protesters: ldquoA lot of people are not fortunate to be able to buy a house close to the beach and they would enjoy the opportunity to walk down there and enjoy a cup of coffee.Fellow ward councillor Sue Kempson called in the application for the van to the committee after planning officers recommended it for approval.At a previous bid to put a snack van on the site two years ago, which was thrown out,Dr Kempson described visitors to the van as having their ldquogrotty coffee, adding:ldquoIrsquom sorry but I have used snack bars and never had decent coffee [from them].Dr Kempson told the committee that she was concerned about the impact of the new snack van, which was being sited at a dferent point of the car park, further away from housing, on thegrass area it was designated.She supported residents concerns about the snack van being on the John Muir Way.She said: ldquoTo give permission for this van on the John Muir site, Dunbar, is to me sacrilege.Jacquie Bell, from Dunbar Community Council, which also objected to the snack van, pointed out that the Shore Road car park was ldquoan anomaly among coastal car parks in East Lothian because it was next to residential streets.She said: ldquoThis is not a NIMBY objection, the priority concern is road safety.And she criticised the council for advertising the site as a potential snack van placement, saying the financial gain for the local authorityof tendering the site was ldquooutweighedby the impact of the van.Bethan and Markos Akgum, who applied for permission to operate the snackvan at the site, said that they had switched to electric batteries and reduced the size of the van, as well as changing its colour, after feedback from the community.Bethan told the committee that plans were in place to monitor litter by using branded compostable containers, which she suggested could be marked with the initials of customers to make them more responsible for disposing of them properly.The efforts of the applicants were welcomed by many councillors on the committee.Mr Hampshire said that he had lived in Dunbar all his le and had fond memories of visiting the bay while growing up and with his family, and the provision of a snack van would be appreciated.He said: ldquoEvery time I am down at Belhaven, someone will come and ask me lsquowhere can I buy a coffee rsquo and there is nowhere, only a long, long walk to buy a cup of coffee.ldquoThe van will be adjacent to the John Muir Way and hundreds of walkers will welcome it. I think it will be an asset to people who use the bay.The committee voted by  votes to one to approve the snack van. Dr Kempson was the only councillor to vote against it.

title: east-lothian-covid-latest-statistics-get-tested
